Award.AwardTitle: Expanding and Refining the Application-Based Service-Learning Pedagogy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project expands the pedagogy of Application-Based Service-Learning (ABSL) from its focus in western Pennsylvania to eight institutions in Pennsylvania, Ohio, and New York. This pedagogy uses five practices documented as having a high impact on student learning: learning communities, writing-intensive courses, collaborative projects, undergraduate research, and service learning. Through ABSL all these practices are incorporated into courses in which students address a community-based problem, such as the possibility that feral cats carry pathogenic microbes, or that areas impacted by mining or manufacturing practices might have altered water quality or issues associated with their redevelopment for other uses. As part of their course work, students collect samples to bring back to their classes for study, and their findings are shared not only within the class but with other ABSL classes and the community at large. In addition to honing their scientific expertise, students learn important skills in written and oral communication and leadership. This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts toward Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Application-Based Service Learning (ABSL) melds five high-impact teaching practices into one novel teaching strategy. These are learning communities, writing intensive courses, collaborative assignments and projects, undergraduate research, and service learning or community-based learning (www.aacu.org/leap/hip.cfm). ABSL courses start with a large community based problem that require several STEM disciplines to understand or solve.  Students learn about the problem through community-based work and conduct novel research on the problem in a course setting. Our goals are to expose more students to novel research and to help them understand how science directly impacts their lives. Research has shown that both of these goals lead to a higher retention of students in the STEM disciplines.

The focus of our grant was expanding ABSL courses from 3 institutions to 7, including  minority-serving, private and public institutions. More disciplines were incorporated into our ABSL projects and new collaborators from other disciplines helped us explore the intersections between the STEM and non-science disciplines that are necessary to solve large, complex community problems and teach all students how to use the scientific method. We documented our best practices on our website (www.ABSLnews.weebly.com) and assessed the courses to determine if they were having an impact on student learning.

 ABSL courses were developed and taught at CUNY (chemistry), Chatham Univ. (landscape architecture), Duquesne Univ. (microbiology, physiology), Juniata College (bioinformatics), La Roche College (biology), Mt Aloysius (biology), and Univ. Akron (geology). Students collaborated on 3 research projects, the microbiology of feral cats, abandoned mine drainage passive remediation and brownfields remediation. 

We assessed the efficacy of the ABSL pedagogy in a number of different ways, depending on the course, number of students and teaching requirement of the ABSL faculty. To examine the affects on content retention, ABSL was compared to a lecture only course the faculty member also taught. After one semester, ABSL resulted in 96% content retention as compared to 61% for a lecture course. Using The Critical Thinking Assessment Test, students in one course had one of the large increases ever seen in critical thinking scores. In several other courses, the Furco Service Learning test indicated significant gains in students’ understanding of their chosen major and confidence in working in that discipline. Using the CURE Survey, students in one course reported large gains in 20 of the 21 questions on the survey. The gains were larger that those reported by students in the Summer Undergraduate Research experience. The most significant gains were in understanding how knowledge is constructed, understanding the research process, ability to integrate theory and practice, learning how scientists think, and learning to work independently. After several courses, we saw a significant increase in the number of students conducting independent research and retention of students in the research lab. Thus, using a number of different tests, we saw significant evidence of student learning, knowledge retention and student involvement in novel research using ABSL.

ABSL had a number of positive impacts on faculty and their universities. ABSL faculty developed cross discipline and cross institution collaborations that continue to flourish. This has resulted in several additional grant submissions, peer-reviewed papers and research collaborations. One institution has established a teaching post doc fellowship to continue developing ABSL projects. ABSL faculty participated in the American Society for Microbiology Scholars program and the GCAT-SEEK Genomic Research Workshop.

One major goal of ABSL is to teach new ways of looking at community and research projects through the perspectives of professionals with different disciplinary backgrounds. By involving many disciplines, we explored the synergistic effects of combining unique knowledge bases into a science-based comprehensive plan to address community problems. The results of our projects were broadly disseminated via the ABSL website, participation of faculty in regional and national conferences and workshops, and submission of manuscripts on both the scientific and the educational aspects of the projects to peer-reviewed journals. ABSL faculty had 7 peer reviewed publications, five with undergraduate authors, 26 poster presentations at scientific meetings, with 15 of these having undergraduate authors, and five invited talks. Our work was broadly disseminated at national and international meetings, with a focus on both the educational pedagogy and the scientific results.

In summary, using community based problems and multidisciplinary approaches to teach students about scientific research has provided students with many unique opportunities for learning and resulted in more students engaged in STEM disciplines.
